definitions.definition: To take hold of, particularly with the hand.
definitions.example: After a few slips, the tires gripped the pavement.

definitions.definition: To help or assist, particularly in an emotional sense.
To do something with another that makes you happy/gives you relief.
definitions.example: Let’s grip (get a coffee, hang, take a break, see a movie, etc.)

definitions.definition: To trench; to drain.
A hold or way of holding, particularly with the hand.
definitions.example: It's good to have a firm grip when shaking hands.

definitions.definition: A handle or other place to grip.
definitions.example: There are several good grips on the northern face of this rock.

definitions.definition: A visual component on a window etc. enabling it to be resized and/or moved.
(film production) A person responsible for handling equipment on the set.
A channel cut through a grass verge (especially for the purpose of draining water away from the highway).
A lot of something.
definitions.example: That is a grip of cheese.

definitions.definition: A long time.
definitions.example: I haven't seen you in a grip.

definitions.definition: A small travelling-bag or gripsack.
An apparatus attached to a car for clutching a traction cable.
Assistance; help or encouragement.
A helpful, interesting, admirable, or inspiring person.
As much as one can hold in a hand; a handful.
definitions.example: I need to get a grip of nails for my project.

definitions.definition: A tenacious grasp; a holding fast.
definitions.example: in the grip of a blackmailer

definitions.definition: A device for grasping or holding fast to something.
Influenza, the flu.
A small ditch or trench; a channel to carry off water or other liquid; a drain.
The griffin.
